ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to speak Spanish better kinda
Improved my verbal and written spanish skills.
Learned a few more tenses of spanish.
I enhanced my ability to speak Spanish more fluently.
Spanish grammar tenses, conversational skills, vocabulary. Definitely an emphasis on speaking, but writing and comprehension are also included.
I learned to contrive answers based on very specific and sometimes restrictive grammatical instructions from my professor.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Weaknesses: the work was very long and not too relevant. It was not engaging. The class was not fun or engaging. I dreaded going to class every day. It was definitely the worst class of my first semester. Choose better stories to read and more engaging topics that are more relevant and applicable
It was very well organized, however, at times it was too organized and rigid.
A lot of homework that is just busy work. Supersite grading and penalties are ridiculous. The amount of large assignments we have week after week is ridiculous.

Weaknesses: Genuinely everything ranging from assignments that did not enhance the learning process, repetitive class activities, uninteresting overall. Strength: Meeting every day was the closest thing to immersion.
The online homework was sometimes irrelevant and frustrating.

The reading material is not something students can relate to--I don't mean by nature of it centering around Latin American culture, but by nature of the storylines centering around either abstract concepts or characters quite far from our age and experience. Since they have to be more basic for this level, they're not at all compelling.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, the only reason I took it was to fulfill a language requirement, and this seems to be the general consensus. Even if you love spanish, you will come out of this course very disappointed and may even like spanish less and be discouraged from taking an L5 course, like I was
Yes, especially to fulfill the language requirement.
No. Not in a million years. Awful. Hard to learn and not at all enjoyable.
I'd recommend this course to someone who is taking it to fulfill their language requirement and is ready to put in quite a bit of work and effort. It is not that hard to get an A if you try.

I would not recommend this course because it does very little for your actual Spanish communication skills--conversations are stilted and structured by the requests of the instructor, and thus it is difficult to adapt more fluidity in your speaking.
